Description: Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
The Unique Ingredient Identifier (UNII, aka "Approval ID") is a unique ID generated for each substance record.
A string representing a user or entity which approved the assignment of UNII, or approval ID.
A description of the reason for the last change to the record.
A list of codes used for this record, containing external identifiers, external classification designations, and external link-outs.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
The level of completeness and specificity of the definition (e.g. "complete", "incomplete", "representative").

The type of definition ("primary" or "alternative"). Primary definitions are the main descriptive form of the substance definition, while "alternative" definitions may be seen as definitional "synonyms" of some primary record.
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
A container for the mixture information necesary to define a mixture substance. This includes the mixture components and an optioanl source material reference.
A container for the set of physical, structural and agent modifications on the substance record.

A list of the important component chemical structures which comprise a chemical substance, as well as their relative ratios to each other (especially important in the case of non-stoichiometric chemical substances). These "moieties" are typically the unique set of disconnected covalent structures found in the substance.

The list of names associated with a record. These include scientific, common, generic and brand names for substances and concepts. Name objects include both the name as a string, as well as other information.
A list of notes and general comments for the record.
The definitional information of a nucleic acid substance. Contains information about the nucleic acid sequence as well as the sugars and linkages used.
The definitional information of a polymer substance. Contains information about the monomers, structural repeat units, amounts, connectivity and idealized structural form of the polymer.
A list of physical, chemical or other properties of the record.
The definitional information of a protein substance. Contains information about the amino acid sequence, gylcosylation, classification, disulfide links and other links.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.
A list of related records which share some known relationship with this record (e.g. salt forms, metabolites, impurities, etc).
The current record status (e.g. "pending", "approved"). This is not a regulatory status, but simply the status of record validation and curation. .

The definitional information of a structurally diverse substance. This includes informaiton about the source of the material (e.g. taxonomy for organisms) as well as the state, form and part of the source material used.
Chemical Structure of a chemical substance.

This value wall always be "reference" if it is intended as a real reference and "mention" if it is a place-holder. However, it can also specify a full substance class, in which case the whole record reference object is meant to be a full entire record rather than a reference.
A collection of strings which mark the reference as having specific properties (nomenclature, spectra, definition, etc).

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
The version of GSRS for which.
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
A list of components found in the mixture. Each component has a type specifying whether it is a necessary/optional element of the mixture, as well as a reference to the substance it specifies. .
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).

A reference to the parent substance which this substance further qualifies. This tends to be null if this record is a "whole" structurally diverse record, and points back to the "whole" record if the part or other qualification is present.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.

A list of agent modifications applied to this substance. An agent modification is an "agent" (usually a substance) which specifically interacted with and permanently altered the original substance material under some specified conditions, forming a new substance.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
A list of physical modifications applied to this substance. A physical modification is a physical interaction (such as heating) where the result permanently alters the original source substance.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.

A list of structural modifications applied to this substance. A stuctural modification is a known and specific change to the original source substane described, where a description of the chemical structural change, location, and amount are feasible.

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The list of linkages used to connect the nucleosides of the nucleic acid, as well as their sites of use.
The type of nucleic acid.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.

The original source of the amino acid sequence. This is a general category which, for organisms, typically specifies a useful general abstract taxonic level with increasing granularity as it approaches humans (e.g. "bacteria","mouse", "mouse chimeric", "human").
The type of sequence being specified (e.g. "incomplete", "complete").

The list of Subunits found in this nucleic acid. Each subunit is described by a sequence of nucleobases. Double stranded nucleic acids should typically be represented by 2 subunits, while single-stranded nucleic acids will more typically be represented with 1.
The list of sugars (e.g. ribose, deoxyribose, morphilino) which the nucleobases connect to, as well as their sites of use within the sequence.

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
A container for classification properties of a polymer.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.

A form of the structure which is meant for displaying a simplified form of the polymer. This display structure is not meant to be trusted as canonical for the polymer definition, but is meant to be useful for communicating a "conceptual" diagram of the polymer.

A form of the structure which is meant for communicating a more accurate, but sometimes less intuitive view of the polymeric structure. This form of the polymer definition is also not meant to be an exhaustive cannonical form, but is meant to be the most compatible aranagement possible for unerstanding the structural units.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).

A list of starting materials and/or conceptual "monomers" that either were used in the synthesis of the polymer, or "could have been used" in its synthesis. Each "monomer" has a type, an extent (or amount) and a reference to another substance record. It is important to note, despite the name, that catalysts and non-monomer starting materials may be captured here as well.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.

A list of SRUs (Structural Repeating Units) as well as non-repeating structural units which comprise the polymer. Each unit present has a chemical structure, a label, an extent/amount, a type and information about how the unit can connect to other units and/or itself. This can be seen as the set of "pieces" which can be combined together to make the polymer in question.

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
The set of disulfide links that connect different cysteine residues to each other via a sulfur-sulfur covalent bond.
Stores information on glycosylation sites and glycosylation type for the protein.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The set of links, other than disulfide links, which connect different amino acid residues found within the protein.
A comma-separated set of subtypes descriptive of the protein.
A general typing of the protein.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.

The original source of the amino acid sequence. This is a general category which, for organisms, typically specifies a useful general abstract taxonic level with increasing granularity as it approaches humans (e.g. "bacteria","mouse", "mouse chimeric", "human").
The type of sequence being specified (e.g. "incomplete", "complete").

The list of Subunits found in this nucleic acid. Each subunit is described by a sequence of nucleobases. Double stranded nucleic acids should typically be represented by 2 subunits, while single-stranded nucleic acids will more typically be represented with 1.

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
The developmental stage of the organism, when necessary to describe the material. (e.g. "adult", "larva", etc).
A general material type of the fraction which is isolated in a structurally diverse substance (e.g. "oils", "cells", etc).
A specific name for the fraction which is isolated in a structirally diverse substance (e.g. "low molecular weight oils").
The scientific name of the species which provided the ovum for a hybrid. Sometimes the left hand side of the "x" in hybrid nomenclature.
The scientific name of the species which provided the sperm for a hybrid. Sometimes the right hand side of the "x" in hybrid nomenclature.
The part of the organisms name that is more specific than the species rank.
The type of rank of the infra specific name such as variety, subspecies, or forma. .
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The author of the organism's scientific name.
The organism's taxonomic family.
The organism's taxonomic genus.
The organism's species scientific name excluding the genus, known as the specific epithet.

A reference to the parent substance which this substance further qualifies. This tends to be null if this record is a "whole" structurally diverse record, and points back to the "whole" record if the part or other qualification is present.
The contiguous physical part(s) of the source material that are isolated in this substance (e.g. "flower", "fruit", "stem", "bone"). Full organisms receive the part of "Whole".
The location of the part(s), if necessary to explain the context of the part.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.
The class of source material (e.g. "organism" or "mineral").
A textual catagorization of what state the material is in, if needed (e.g. "live", "killed").

The type of source material. This is a general category which, for organisms, typically specifies a useful general abstract taxonic level with increasing granularity as it approaches humans (e.g. "plant", "fungus", "mammal", "primate", "human").

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
Whether or not the record has atropisomerism, or has a chirality where a hindered rotation about a single bond as a resolt of steric or electronic constraints.
The net charge of the structure.
The exact number of times that the structure is repeated.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A count of defined stereocenters.
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
A hash of the raw structural information encoded.
A count of E/Z, or absolute double bond stereochemistry centers.
The chemical formula of the record.
A hash of the defining structural information. Here, the lychi layer 4 is used.
The identifier of the structural element itself (this is still a UUID).
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The chemical structure in MDL Molfile format (V2000).
The molecular weight of the structure.

The optical activity or rotation of the material. "(+)" and "(-)" are used for optically active materials where activity is known and significantly useful for definition. "(+-)" is used for racemic mixtures.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.
The chemical structure in SMILES format.
A count of possible stereocenters.
The structure's type of stereochemistry (absolute, achiral, racemic, etc.).
Some textually descriptive information about specific stereochemistry that cannot adequately be captured elsewhere.
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
The literal code value.
The orginizational system which defines the code meaning (e.g. the originating database or classification system).
Any comments regarding the relationship.

The type of the name (e.g. "bn" for "brand name", "cn" for "common name", and "sys" for "systematic name", etc).
The url to further information regarding this code.

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
The set of sites where the protein is c-glycosylated.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.

The type of glycosylation pattern found on the protein. Here, this is a very general term meant to capture the organism-level pattern that the glycosylation roughly corresponds to. (e.g. "mouse", "human", "porcine").
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The set of sites where the protein is n-glycosylated.
The set of sites where the protein is c-glycosylated.

True if this is to be the displayed name for the substance.
The list of domains that this name is used in (e.g. "drug", "cosmetic", etc).
The list of languages that use that name as written (ISO 639-1 codes).

The value or amount that describes the relationship between the two records. An amount is not always present, but sometimes quantifies the interaction between two records in some context (e.g. "the IC50 for an inhibitor").

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.
The Unique Ingredient Identifier (UNII, aka "Approval ID") is a unique ID generated for each substance record.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record (or element) was created (or sometimes exported) in its original form.
A string representing a user or entity which originally created the record (or element).
A boolean marking for whether the element or record is considered deprecated.
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The approvalID of the record if it exists, otherwise some compact and exchangable ID useful for linking to the referenced record (often the first 8 chars of its uuid).
The literal string text of a name.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.
The "Priority Name" (usually the display name) of the record being referenced.
The UUID of the related record.

This value wall always be "reference" if it is intended as a real reference and "mention" if it is a place-holder. However, it can also specify a full substance class, in which case the whole record reference object is meant to be a full entire record rather than a reference.

A textual description of a value which can not be quantified numerically. For example, "solubility" may be described quantitatively or it may be described with certain textual categories. Non-numeric values are meant to specify qualitative values and other values not easily described by numbers or ranges of numbers.

The amount's unit of measurement.

A list of explicit detailed sites where the linkage is applicable. A linkage site is always describing how the nucleoside connects to the NEXT nucleoside in the series. So a sequence of length 2 will have only 1 linkage, specified at the 1st site (not the second).
The shorthand form of the sites where the linkage is used. Here, "1_1" means the first subunit's first residue, and "2_3-2_7" means the second subunit's 3rd residue through its 7th residue.
Marking the record or element as belonging to certain groups for use in tracking which groups should receive visibility, export and/or inclusion in specific reports.

The role that the physical modification has in the process of the modification.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.

The type of extent for the structural modification. "Complete" if the extent is considered to have 100% occupancy / replacement, "partial" otherwise.

A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The type of location specification for a residue modified in a structural modification. (e.g. "site-specific" or "residue-specific").

A key specifying how this modification relates to other modifications. All modifications sharing a group key are considered to be occuring as part of a single process or event, or descriptive of the same change to the substance.

A reference to the substance which is substituting, binding or connecting to the main substance and thus modifying it. For proteins, this is most typically a full amino acid which is considered to replace an existing amino acid at a specific site. For nucleic acids, this is more commonly a full nucleotide which is also considered to replace the linkage, sugar and nucleobase at some specified site(s).

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.
The residue which was modified for the structural modification (necessary if the modification is residue specific instead of site-specific).

The highest allowable numeric value usable for the amount. (highest limit).
A UNIX timestamp marking when the record was last edited (or sometimes exported) to form the record (or element) in its current state.
A string representing a user or entity which last edited the record (or element).
The lowest numerical value likely for the average amount. (lowest average).
The lowest allowable numeric value usable for the amount. (lowest limit).

A textual description of a value which can not be quantified numerically. For example, "solubility" may be described quantitatively or it may be described with certain textual categories. Non-numeric values are meant to specify qualitative values and other values not easily described by numbers or ranges of numbers.

A list of reference uuids, which refer back to the root record's references, essentially acting as footnotes. The included references are considered to be the supporting origins of the data element in question.
The type of the name (e.g. "bn" for "brand name", "cn" for "common name", and "sys" for "systematic name", etc).
The amount's unit of measurement.

A Universally Unique Identifier (also sometimes called a GUID) for the element. Most GSRS elements have a uuid to be used for tracking, processing and referencing a record (and any element of that record).

This value wall always be "reference" if it is intended as a real reference and "mention" if it is a place-holder. However, it can also specify a full substance class, in which case the whole record reference object is meant to be a full entire record rather than a reference.
